Reviews.Title: I love this camera, except....
Reviews.Author: Michael L. Andrews
Reviews.Content: I love everything about this camera, except.... it takes a terrible picture.The good:  The form factor is great  I like the way you slide the cover to open the lens and turn the camera on.  Makes turning on fast and easy.  The touch screen is great.  Very easy to change settings.  Screen is responsive. You can touch where you want to focus, which is really cool.  The ability to shoot in 16:9 ratio is nice, but you're limited to 8MP in that mode.The Bad  This camera just wouldn't take a good picture.  Outside in daylight I could get a pretty good photo, but anything indoors was poor at best.  Even indoors during the day when there's decent light.  After taking my first set of shots I assumed I must be doing something wrong, so I read the manual, tried all the different "scenes", I tried adjusting ISO, resolution, etc.Granted, I'm a fairly novice user, so perhaps a more experienced pro could get a better picture out of this camera.  I finally pulled out my old Canon SD200 3.2MP camera that I was looking to replace.  I took many photos side by side.  I never took the Canon off "auto" mode and I tweaked the Nikon a million ways.  Virtually every time the Canon was sharper, and more color accurate.So, I thouht maybe I got a bad camera.  I went to Best Buy and tried their display model.  You could see on the camera screen that the images just weren't that great. Maybe if I didn't have a side by side comparison it wouldn't have been so noticable, but I really expected this Nikon to be better than my very old Canon.If anyone believes it's the operator and not the camera I'm more than open to advice, because I loved everything else about this camera.  I did return it, but would buy it again if I found out it was just operator error, however, I really don't think it was my error.

Reviews.Title: Come on Nikon!!
Reviews.Author: M. Mcpheeters "shooter"
Reviews.Content: The above reviewer hit the nail on the head, Great design, functionality, touchscreen is the only way to go...But, the camera will not take a sharp photo. I took my card into the store and shot numerous people and signs at all iso'sand image styles and basically I got mush. I brought my card home and opened it in Photoshop and no amount of tweeking or sharpening could save these images. It boggles my mind that a company like Nikon will release such a camera.Look for this $400 camera to be $125 by Christmas. Hint to Nikon, all the features in the world won't sell a camera if it won't take a decent image.

Reviews.Title: Great features, disappointing results
Reviews.Author: Bob D.
Reviews.Content: When I first read the specs on this camera I was very excited about getting my hands on it.  I was especially interested in the OLED touch screen and the compact lens design.  I went ahead and purchased the camera despite the mixed reviews it has received so far.There are several problems with this camera.  First, I took a number of shots both indoor and out on several settings and the picture quality is not very good.  The pictures taken on my old 5 MP Minolta Dimage are far superior to this camera.  Second, the design of the camera makes it almost completely unusable in normal shooting situations.  The OLED screen takes up the entire back of the camera and is very touch sensitive. I found myself inadvertently activating functions without intending to.  Also, the location of the lens is so close to the side of the camera my fingers continually ended up getting in the photo. So between the touchscreen and the lens location you end up with a continual camera holding balancing act that you can't win.Overall a great feature set, but less than adequate picture quality and design.  I returned it and purchased the Panasonic DMC-ZS3, and having now tried it out it beats the Nikon hands down.

Reviews.Title: The S70 - A Nikon Winner
Reviews.Author: James Beverly
Reviews.Content: The new S70 lives up to all of the Nikon claims. Like most Nikon cameras I have owned, it functioned perfectly right out of the box. Having been highly disappointed with the previous S60, this new S70 seems to have corrected all of the shortcomings of the S60 and much more. The new OLED touch screen is a joy to use - sensitive and responsive. The screen visibility and clarity is excellent under all lighting conditions. Nikon also substituted a more robust battery which in combination with the OLED panel should extend camera use between charges. Perhaps more important is the clarity and sharpness of the images taken with the S70. They are impressively sharp and clear under magnification. The menus are intuitive and easy to navigate. The touch screen focus and shutter release function is a nice touch. The simplified and enhanced in-camera cropping and retouch functions are well done and welcome additions. The Easy Auto mode handles very well all of the major camera settings and functions required for a good picture when a quick "point & shoot" situation arises. I would have preferred however an out-of-camera battery recharging system as I usually charge and carry a spare battery. I will be purchasing an external charger.I have owned Nikon film and digital cameras for the last 25 years and I consider my new S70 to be a very worthwhile addition. It is stylish, functional, fun to use, and takes great photos. When you need a high quality pocket sized camera, you should take a close look at this one.  I would highly recommend the S70.

Reviews.Title: Great pictures when set correctly, but touchscreen is very annoying
Reviews.Author: Just a guy
Reviews.Content: I think this is a great camera and have achieved some terrific pictures with it.  The problem, as stated in another review, is that the image sensor does not do well with high ISOs.  I find that setting it to max out at around 800 yields the best photos.  The VR zoom is a huge benefit to keep photos in focus.  I recommend using a fast memory card to reduce (and eliminate) shutter lag.The only drawback is the touchscreen in the back.  When I first started using the camera I found myself touching it inadvertantly and doing things I didn't intend.  With a small amount of experience with the camera I don't do that anymore and I have learned where to put my fingers to avoid the touchscreen.  The screen itself is beautiful - among the very best I have seen on a camera back (I suspect it is similar to the one I have on my D3000 Nikon SLR - although that isn't a touch screen).  The touch sensitivity cannot be altered (as far as I can tell), so it still poses an issue when I you hand the camera to someone else to take a photo.Overall, I really like the camera and it takes nice photos when set correctly.  The touchscreen and lack of quality high ISO result in the deduction of one star - I would probably have given 3 1/2 if I could, but the high quality of Nikon products generally biases me towards rounding up, not down.

Reviews.Title: Big problems
Reviews.Author: Sandy "bocagal"
Reviews.Content: The features are great, the design of the touch screen is clever, but if you default to the touch screen, it is way too easy to mistakenly touch the screen and take photos you don't want.  But, most importantly, I'm surprised by the other reviewers who say the photos are great as I think the photo quality is very poor.  I've tried various auto options and have tested all the manual settings and cannot get a really good photo. I'm not new to Nikon - I've had other Nikon Coolpix cameras that I loved and I also have the Nikon D300 SLR and have been a Nikon owner for 40 years but this one is the worst...sorry to say!

Reviews.Title: Make sure to cap the Auto ISO setting to 80-200
Reviews.Author: M. Lopez "California Groovin"
Reviews.Content: I have not tried the S70 yet (so disregard star rating) but I have noticed several reviews with frustrations about poor image quality. I also saw in the CNET Editor's review that they suggested that the user sets the Auto ISO limit to 80-200 for best results in most conditions and 80-400 max under difficult lighting conditions. Anyone who is experiencing photo quality issues might want to try that to see if it makes a big improvement. I expect that it will make a big difference since CNET said the pictures were "very good for a snapshot camera" once those settings have been changed. My guess is for some reason the camera is trying to use a ridiculously high ISO setting (1200-6400) and producing predictably grainier photos as a result. As Wikipedia explains regarding ISO speeds, "In both digital and film photography, the reduction of exposure corresponding to use of higher [ISO] sensitivities generally leads to reduced image quality (via coarser film grain or higher image noise of other types)." If that is in fact the problem it would still be a design flaw but one with perhaps a simple and very tolerable workaround.From CNET:"The photo quality from the S70 is very good for a snapshot camera...The camera lets you limit the auto ISO range to either 80-200 or 80-400. If you're in daylight or bright conditions, I recommend locking it down to 80-200. Again, it did perform well through ISO 400, but it's at its best below ISO 200."Good luck with that workaround.Also, anyone who has problems tapping the screen by accident should probably set the camera to only use the shutter button.I still like the specs of this camera so plan to check it out at the local Best Buy with my own SD card and I will be playing with these settings and I will update my review once I have.

Reviews.Title: Fine camera
Reviews.Author: P. Mrozinski "mstudio"
Reviews.Content: My wife bought me the S70 for Christmas, she saw a commercial on TV and thought I'd enjoy the camera. As a disclaimer, I should mention that I am a professional photographer and have been since the mid-70s. I know what shutter speeds and F stops are and how they can affect image quality and final look.I do not agree with the reviewers that talk about poor image quality, I do agree with the ones that suggest you learn how to use the camera. It is true that in low light situations, the camera is not always accurate with it's touch screen auto focus. I have found that using the shutter release instead totally solves that problem. I've also taken a few shots of my thumb because of the lens placement, but hey, they were sharp and well exposed.The iPod-like viewing of the photos on the screen with the swipe action is brilliant. I've been using it in my business as my "Polaroid" shots to quickly show clients camera angles without them messing with my other equipment. I'm also involved in a construction project now and the camera has been great to create my punch list, way better than writing everything down.I'm not too crazy about the in-camera charging of the battery, so I purchased another battery and external charger; always a good idea anyway.I first looked at the S70 as a toy to just have some fun with, but I have been completely satisfied with this camera and find myself putting it in my pocket whenever I leave the house. I'm confident it will produce what you are looking for in a point and shoot and I'm also glad my wife saw that commercial...

Reviews.Title: picture quality
Reviews.Author: A. Cummings "Big TV Fan"
Reviews.Content: I don't normally write reviews on products in Amazon, but after receiving this camera for christmas and then seeing all the negative reviews, I had do write something.All the negative reviews are mostly related to picture quality. Granted, when I got the camera out and started snapping pictures, I was freaked out, because most all of the pictures looked pretty horrible. I tweaked settings and tried indoors and outdoors and most all came out fuzzy.But that's just the playback on the camera!! I plugged it into my laptop and transferred them to my computer and all of the pictures look great. While it sucks that the onscreen playback blows, what matters is the quality of the actual picture files. I'm thinking all the negative reviews about picture quality are from those that are simply looking at the photos on the camera, not their computer.Put 'em on your computer!! I probably would've given this camera 4 stars, but figured I had to do something about the average rating....

Reviews.Title: S 70 Review
Reviews.Author: James Stitley "Jim Stitley"
Reviews.Content: I ordered one for my wife and one for me. After reading all the negative reviews on picture quality, I almost returned them on arrival. But I didn't and both me and my wife weer pleasantly amazed at the ease of use and high quality pictures we got immediately. I suspect people play with the settings and especially the high iso one and end of with less resolution for low light which may not be needed anyway. The auto function works extemely well as it select the best scene, focus and shutter. All our initial pictures were just perfect, even under less than idea conditions. For my book I give it an overall 4.5, and that is just because the camera is still new and still learning the full features, I would recommencd it as others have. None were blurred.

Reviews.Title: Recommended with caveats
Reviews.Author: Mickey
Reviews.Content: I own the S70 and used it Christmas Eve with family for the first time (a kind of acid-test.) I spent a few hours analyzing the results and overall I am very well pleased with this camera (replaced the Nikon S51.) I've owned many digital cameras going back into the 1990's when they were sub-megapixel, so I am no stranger to strange behavior in any particular model.With the S70, the confusion seems to come with 2 different Auto modes: Auto (Easy) and Auto. When using the "easy" Auto mode, the camera makes scene mode decisions for the user and I found results in this mode to be lower-than-expected and on par with many of the negative comments posted. When switched to Auto mode with forced fill-in flash, the camera performed very well in every situation and the picture detail and tonal quality were excellent and the digital 'noise' and artifacts were minimized. Obviously, you can continue to customize the workings of the unit to fine-tune performance and quality as some other reviewers have suggested; but this is a point-n-shoot camera, so over customization will require you to re-tune when shooting in other modes.You are not required to touch the screen to release the shutter; a conventional shutter release button is available.I have not yet taken it outside for action shots and landscapes, but other reviewers have comments in this area.As far as the touch screen is concerned, it takes a little getting used to... some will love it and some will hate it... same as the iPhone love/hate relationship. If you purchase this camera, give yourself the opportunity to fully explore the touch screen over time and my belief is that you will not be disappointed. If you do not like the thought of touching the screen for all the settings and functions, stay away from this model.I plan on buying another one as a graduation gift; the iTouch group immediately fall in love with this unit.

Reviews.Title: Poor Pictures.  Poor Screen.
Reviews.Author: J. Sciabica
Reviews.Content: A camera should do 1 thing first: Take good pictures.  Everything after that is a bonus.  Unfortunately, this camera does not do the first thing, so everything else is irrelevant.I could go on about what the camera does well, but as I said, it simply doesn't matter.  The one feature that I was most surprised with is the screen itself.  Though large and bright, picture all have noticeable aliasing (jaggy edges)which makes it even harder to tell if the picture you just took is good or bad.

Reviews.Title: Fuzzy S70
Reviews.Author: Palmer W. Agnew "longtime nikon user"
Reviews.Content: I was intrigued by the Nikon S70's advertized automation features and iPhone-like interface. Of course, I first checked Amazon's reviews to see if thre were any gotchas. Several reviews told me to beware of fuzzy picture quality. Therefore, when I went to the local high-end camera store, I took along my old Nikon P5100 for comparison purposes. I took full-wide-angle pictures of the interior of the store with both cameras. Using playback mode on both cameras' display screens, I expanded the resulting pictures so that the printing on a store display filled the screen. The S70 showed intolerably fuzzy printing, while my old camera showed perfectly sharp printing. Without Amazon's reviews, I would have trusted Nikon's name, purchased the S70, and had to go to the trouble of returning it.

Reviews.Title: Nikon S70 Disaster
Reviews.Author: George Bratton
Reviews.Content: In April I purchased a Nikon S70 camera in preparation for a two-week trip to South Korea and Japan. Not wanting to lug along a large format camera, I thought the Nikon S70 would be the perfect size. Besides, what better brand to purchase than a Nikon? Unfortunately, it proved to be an exceptionally poor camera. Had I read the reviews posted on amazon.com prior to purchasing the camera, I would have chosen something else.  Being a somewhat experienced photographer, I thought I could make good use of the Nikon S70, despite the negative reviews. Of the 1000+ photos I took, more than 75% were fuzzy, out of focus, poorly lighted, or had to be deleted. It was a once-in-a-lifetime trip and I'd hoped to come home with some good photographic memories. Needless to say, I was greatly disappointed. I've returned the camera to amazon.com. While the size of the camera was what I was expecting, the sensitivity of the touch screen and certain other features force you handle the camera with great care to prevent changing various settings or accidentally taking an unwanted photo. The lack of sharp focus was the worst issue with the camera. It seemed confused under certain lighting conditions. Apparently Nikon has discontinued this particular model, which is a good decision. Nikon's larger and more expensive cameras are among the best on the market, but this little device is a total disaster. Do not purchase one under any circumstances.

Reviews.Title: Great Camera
Reviews.Author: SLY
Reviews.Content: The camera is great.  I had the S60 and was a little disappointed with the response time to the touch screen, but they have fixed all of that with the S70.  The screen brightness is great and the touch is responsive.  The internal optical zoom is nice and you don't have lens moving outside of the case.  The only downside (minor) is the lens is in the top left corner and at first was easily covered by your finger when you hold the camera.  This was easy to see and correct.  Quality is great.

Reviews.Title: Pictures not so cool
Reviews.Author: J. Recinto "Blue Eagle"
Reviews.Content: Coolpix S70 takes good pictures under normal light without flash. Takes good pictures indoors with dim light without flash. But using flash indoors results in too white (washed) picture. Design, construction and most features are excellent. But I didn't like the feature that uses only Nikon Transfer or ViewNX to transfer pictures to computer. I wish there is a way to transfer photos to PC with just a USB cable and put the pictures in any folder you want. Coolpix limits you to ViewNX only.

Reviews.Title: Everything but the Picture
Reviews.Author: Anthony Pontarelli
Reviews.Content: This camera has everything. Every option the novice would ever need...ISO adjustment, black & white option, high mega-pixel, touch screen, etc.  I was willing to pay more for the touch screen and it did not disappoint.  After becoming quit comfortable with my ipod-touch...this touch screen was a welcome new toy.  I read all the reviews and most had the same theme...fun camera, loved the touch-screen but didn't take quality pictures.  I threw caution into the wind and ignored the negative.  I was in love with this touch screen idea.  Anyway, after playing around for a while I found option after option including the ability to crop your photos right there on the camera...how great is that?  I could even turn a regular photo to black & white with the push of a button.  So what's the problem you ask?  ...and why the negative review?Plain & simple the reviews were dead on...CAMERA DOESN'T TAKE GOOD PICTURES.  I should add that it did take some clear pictures but if I had to assign a percentage I would say 80% of the picture were blurry.  I read every review on how to adjust the ISO & everything else.  I even took it to my buddy the camera tech geek.  He had no luck in getting consistent quality pictures either.  He said the camera was just "too gimicky."  I took the camera out New Years Eve and out of the 20 or 30 pics we took...only 3 were good quality (very dissapointing).  So while I loved the camera for it's options, size & touch-screen...it just didn't take consistent quality pictures.I have since returned the camera and purchased a Cannon elph (dont remember the exact name or model).  All I want is a small portable camera that takes reasonably good quality pictures.  I don't know much about camera's at all and don't really want too...just want to shoot & view, print and most importantly capture memories.  This new Cannon was cheaper and out of the box took great quality pictures...probably 90%-95% of my pics are crystal clear and I didn't have to do a thing...just point and click.  I strongly recommend waiting until Nikon fixes the picture quality before buying.  Hope this helps.

Reviews.Title: touch screen! love it!
Reviews.Author: Stephen L. Winarto "ilovesnowboard"
Reviews.Content: Have this black nikon s70 for two weeks and loving every bit of it!!! very easy to use with auto mode! loving the touch screen tech and clarity of video !! use when i went snowboarding, ,am amazed at how the pictures turn out to be clear on fast moving object! am getting another one since i lost mine in the ski resort restroom!bummer! :( Have to get another one regardless the price, just loving this camera!the size is slightly bigger and its not slim, but its OK. the 5x zoom works wonder with the touch screen zoom in and out! i am in no way a camera expert but this camera has a lot of features yet easy to use!gonna buy another one now!!look around and u will find a deal, i got the first one for $255 from adorama and this one frm amazon for $232.49!! what a deal! =)

Reviews.Title: Terrible pictures
Reviews.Author: R. Ortega
Reviews.Content: I have previously owned a Nikon Coolpix S220 for about 10 months and was very pleased with the picture quality of camera.  I gave it to may son and I bought the S70 for Christmas.  I like everything about the camera except the picture quality.  All of my indoor pictures (with or without flash) are very grainy - outdoor pictures are OK.  I have tried the Easy Auto mode as well as the Auto mode playing with various settings to no avail. Resetting  the camera to factory defaults yield the same problem.  I have read other reviews here and agree - stay away from this model.

Reviews.Title: Poor operational design
Reviews.Author: Paul Mahoney
Reviews.Content: As with most Nikon products the camera is made very well, but the S70 is not designed very well.  Since the device has a touch-screen feature that interferes with taking pictures.  The device should have a physical border that allows the user to hold the camera without activating the touch screen.Myself and a number of family and friends tried using the camera, but we all the same issue with touch-screen interfering with picture taking.  Nikon should have performed some additional usability tests with actual end-users, this is simple issue to resolve by either shrinking the touch-screen surface size in increase camera body size.  Either solution would allow the user to hold the camera without touching the touch-screen.

Reviews.Title: Great!
Reviews.Author: D. S. McPherson "techieluvr"
Reviews.Content: Just got this camera for Christmas. I am so glad I didn't listen to all the people who said it was a terrible camera. It took me seconds to play with the settings and take really crisp images. Honestly if you buy a camera for the cool factor alone expect to be disappointed. I am the ultimate Techie and I like the bells and whistles that came with this camera. I feel that all the people that gave this camera such terrible reviews should have really taken the time to get to know the camera first before they decided it was junk. I really love this camera, its not perfect but it really lives up to its claims

Reviews.Title: Horrible pictures
Reviews.Author: kdrenee
Reviews.Content: I saw mixed reviews on this camera but I wanted to try a touch screen. I took this camera on vacation and the pictures were horrible. They were all blurry and it is very inconvenient if you want a fast picture. It was so easy to accidentally touch something and a setting changed and the picture was ruined. If you are using this where it is cold do not wear gloves because the touch screen is almost impossible to use. I found that it took a long time between shots and also the camera froze twice in the one week that I had it. There is absolutely no room to put your hands and it is so easy to take an unwanted picture. The features seem great at first but even the smile detection would not work the way it was supposed to. I could not wait to return this camera and I went with a cannon and I am very happy about my choice. The pictures on my cannon are amazing and the image stabilization is great.

Reviews.Title: Lemmings or What?
Reviews.Author: RG Dillon
Reviews.Content: I own two of these camera's - both bought here on Amazon - one back in December 2009 and the other last month, August 2012.  I keep one in my briefcase and one in my truck's console. I am not a professional photographer.  The primary function of these cameras for me is everyday stuff for when I don't feel like carrying my full size Canon DSLR. That said I just don't understand how there are so many negative reviews for bad picture quality (and even one because the person dropped and broke it - it's a camera, not a rubber ball) - and I end up with two cameras that take excellent photographs.  The odds would appear to certainly not be in my favor.  At least one of these according to all the reviews should be a piece of crap camera - if not both.Maybe I'm doing something wrong?  I did review the manual before using to familiarize myself with the controls - maybe that was a mistake.  I also don't judge quality by the camera screen - instead I download to my computer.  That could be the problem there you think?  I don't use the manual controls very often - mostly just the auto modes with the occasional selection of a specific scene to match the conditions. Starting to get bummed out here, really would like to jump on the bandwagon.Seriously folks - own two as I said and they both take excellent pictures.  I like the array of controls it comes with.  I like the size and weight.  Battery life is very good.  I love the slide up/down front that covers the lens.  Throw a 16 gig card in it and you can take over 7,000 pictures without downloading.Does it take the same quality photographs as my $2,000.00 Canon?  No.  Of course not. Most people couldn't tell the difference though.When I get a little time here I'll upload a few photos so the EXIF data can be viewed and quality compared.

Reviews.Title: A Fun to Use Camera That DOES Take Great Snapshots
Reviews.Author: MrSteveP
Reviews.Content: Firstly, I see how polarizing this camera is. Good/Bad, Love It/Hate It, etc.My background is from an "enthusiasts" or "advanced amateur's" point of view.I love to play with exposure, F-Stops, ISO, shutter speed, white balance et al.My cameras are able to do all that. But I decided that I wanted a simple point and shoot ultracompact "snapshot" camera. With that descision made one must also have reasonable expectations for such a camera. You must not compare it to a DSLR or other advanced point and shoot cameras as that is not fair or balanced. The Nikon S70 does in fact take very, very nice photos. I have taken some scenic outdoor shots that compare to more expensive cameras that I own. The lens is not terribly fast at F3.9 & the flash is not very powerful so indoors it can be more challenging. I actually found that the "Easy Auto" setting which analyzes the shot you are taking and picks the best combination of ISO, aperture and shutter speed works best! This camera is also not meant to be fast as far as shot to shot time, so you would not want to use it to follow fast moving subjects, although I did "pan" around and chased down a squirrel with no blur. The camera also has a "WOW" factor with the touchscreen & touch shutter. In fact the camera is devoid of buttons except the shutter release which you only have to use once you are in the digital zoom range. As someone who enjoys cameras this was not a necessary purchase, but it is a blast to use, it's built extremely well and is fun to use. Lastly as the old saying goes, "the best camera is the one you have with you". I carry this with me most of the time and with a quick slide of the lens cover, the camera powers up very fast and bang, I have captured an image I might not have gotten if A)I did not have a camera with me or B)Had to put my camera in the correct shooting mode & fiddle with settings. There is a niche for a camera like this and even if you are a camera snob or serious photographer, you can still have fun taking photos with a forward thinking, unique camera.

Reviews.Title: Terrible Camera
Reviews.Author: C. MCCABE
Reviews.Content: I bought this camera for my partner for Christmas because he needed to upgrade his camera, and this seemed like the coolest camera out there, and Nikon is a good brand. I have always bought Canon cameras, but since it wasn't for me, I figured this would be fine, but I don't like the camera at all, nor does my partner.First of all, and most importantly, the pictures look awful.The display is big and nice, but it covers nearly the entire back of the camera, so everytime you touch it, the settings are changed or it takes a picture. Icons show up all over the display, and it's not clear which does what, so you spend a lot of time poking around looking for how to fix the horrible pictures it's taking.The camera is quick and easy to turn on, which means it's also very easy to turn on accidentally (inside the camera case) and drain your battery.It's not worth the money unless all you care about is the look of the camera. It's too complicated and takes horrible pictures.

Reviews.Title: Another Super Buy from Amazon.com
Reviews.Author: Eugene Zopp "Gene Zopp"
Reviews.Content: Another Super Buy from Amazon.com.  I have come to check this site before I make any retail purchase because of their super prices and quality of merchandise.  This Nikon Coolpix s70 is just another example.  The $239.99 price was by far the best price I could find anywhere.  The shipping was free and fast.  I love all the features of the camera and the quality of the pics.  Now I can email my grandkid pics and put them on my facebook account with great ease.  This is a very user friendly camera. Just read the instruction manual and go for it!  Plus I was able to find added accessories on Amazon at very reasonable prices.  For example I was able to find a backup battery for the camera at a fraction of the retail price.  I will be back!

Reviews.Title: Way To Go Nikon!!!
Reviews.Author: GypsieBella
Reviews.Content: Completely Awesome Camera!!! I was a bit skeptical by the time I finished reading so many negative reviews, to say the least. After receiving this camera, I am thankful I didn't take the reviews too seriously. I LOVE, LOVE, LOVE THIS CAMERA!!!!!! EXCELLENT PICTURE QUALITY NO MATTER WHAT THEY MAY SAY........  I AM, MOST DEFINITELY, IMPRESSED!  Nikon has lived up to their reputation, yet again.

Reviews.Title: unsure if I like this camara

Reviews.Title: this is a great product!

Reviews.Content: I love this camera. The pictures are great and the touch screen is just like I wanted. It's easy to use even if aren't good with the setting, there scene setting that make it simple. Reviews.Title: Good camera, horrible connectivity
Reviews.Author: M. Lyke
Reviews.Content: Great camera until you try to connect to your computer and not realize that you have to use "approved" sd cards for your computer to recognize it.  I had already purchased a Transcend 16gb series 6, I can't believe this brand isn't "approved."  Test show that it's on par with Sandisk and I use it in my $6500 Sony EX1 and it performs great, and my usb picks it up just fine.  BAD MOVE NIKON!!Anyway, my only other complaint is that we can't zoom during video recording, other than digital zoom which looks horrible.  Our 3 year old powershot s3 did it just fine I don't know why camera developers aren't putting this in as a feature compared to all other useless crap they put in. Reviews.Title: 3 months old and screen is half black
Reviews.Author: P. Oconnell
Reviews.Content: Gave this to my Grandson for Christmas; he just called me and said the screen was half black. I went on the internet and googled this complaint and found the third headline was about the same problem. I had told him not to ask for this camera because the reviews were not good. I have had nikon cameras since the 60"s and always felt the name Nikon stood for quality; not anymore. With the wide array of picture quality reviews and problems, I have to guess that the demand was so great for this now cool camera, that they outsourced its manufacture to some of those companies that make stuff to fill the 99cents stores. Camera was sent to Nikon 4/9 and is currently on parts hold, I was told the parts would'nt be here until 4/29 and then they will proceed to fix it. Nikon never again.Update-4/29 has come and gone and no part arrived. I called last evening and was told by Gabriel (who is in the Dominican Republic) that the part has still not arrived. How can anyone believe this. The camera was received by them 4/10 and 2 days later the status was b1 which is needs minor repair, and it was put on parts hold. An e-mail I received this a.m 4/4 says the parts will not arrive for another 10 days which will make 5 weeks on parts hold. This particular model is a lemon. Today I was also told that the part needed was an lcd screen; I wouldn't consider that a minor repair of part.-New update-I was told that the new date for part to arrive was Wed. May 12th. I Called customer service and left a message detailing my outrage; I received no reply but the camera was just delivered today May 10th, exactly 1 month from the day they received it. Previously I stated that their rating repair b1 was for a minor repair, that should read moderate repair. I will leave it to you to figure out the why of this, but I imagine thousands of these lemons waiting for repair. No more Nikons for me. (At least not the amateur ones)--July 17th 2010-The camera does not work again. Its not even 3 mos. since last repair. Nikon has the camera 2 weeks and I'm still on parts hold-my request for a new or equal value different camera was ignored.

Reviews.Title: I like it!
Reviews.Author: Concord Hill
Reviews.Content: I like this camera.  I was a little intimidated by all the icons & options, but I just started taking pictures.  At first, indoor pictures weren't that good, but using the "auto" or "indoor/party" scene, they now look great.  The touch screen, with all the setting you can change accidentally, takes some getting used to, but once you do, you find there are some advantages to it that other cameras don't have.  We had a very wet fall here, so we found lots of interesting fungi in the woods.  Some of them are very colorful but tiny.  I set the camera on the ground with the lens side downward, touched the screen to focus where I wanted, & let the camera take the picture.  Of course, the good thing about digital cameras is you can take enough shots to get a few good ones, then just delete what isn't perfect.  We got a lot of fantastic pictures, including the undersides of mushrooms a half inch tall.  We also have a Doberman puppy we take many pictures & videos of, and they've turned out fine.  Sunsets turn out great.  I agree with some other reviewers that the most negative reviews come from people who haven't had time to learn how to use the camera.  Having said that, I agree that this camera may not be for everyone.  My husband loves the super macro photos but gets frustrated with the touchscreen.  Being a two camera family, we have the best of both worlds.

Reviews.Title: Was kind of worried
Reviews.Author: Teresa Hild
Reviews.Content: Researching cameras to get an easy portable camera to take on vacations, trips, etc., I saw the ad for this camera, the Nikon Coolpix S70. Of course, it will never be the same as my digital SLR camera, but who can expect that with a small, point-and-shoot camera.  I am very happy!

Reviews.Content: I purchased this camera for a vacation in Europe. I took over 1500 photos, many are nice, many are great, and a few are breath taking. I took a small tripod and it was a life saver during the night shots.It does not have individual controls for the exposure time or F-Stop settings, but it does have many different pre-set modes that will allow you to take excellent photos. It can take a little practice to find the pre-set that suits your particular setting, but it is probably there.*I have my favorite photo from my trip in a 24 x 32 frame on the wall. The details are still sharp and clear, even with this enlargement. I can't explain why my camera takes such great photos and other's take such horrible ones.**This is an edit to my original review as I have read some of the people's bad experiences with the camera. This is my second Nikon Coolpix (first one was the 5700) and my third digital camera.*Remember..Practice, Practice, Practice and your experience with this camera will be great.The battery life is quite long as one day I snapped over 200 photos on the same battery.

Reviews.Title: Pocket Photo-Video Diary / Digital Photo Album Plus a great little camera.
Reviews.Author: Gary Sparks "golf junkie"
Reviews.Content: I bought this camera in March of 2010. I paid $279 new for a black one. I feel it was worth every penny, but I do find it annoying that you can buy a new one today for half that. Buy it, if your looking for that kind of advice. I bought the S70 because I finally admitted to myself that I was never going to take the time, nor did I have an interest in, learning to use all the complicated features on my 'nice but not for amateurs'  Minolta SLR digital, which was big, expensive, and always set on auto anyway. I was attracted to S70 for the style, slim size (think deck of cards), and the idea it had only one button and the large display (the entire back) as viewfinder, (that's it by the way, there is no little hole to peer through), playback, touchscreen functions, etc.  Simple. I bought a cool leather case so that I can wear it on my belt, and have carried it every day since I got it . I have read the bad reviews about this camera, and I have experienced all of the problems others have encountered. Learning to set the ISO properly, whatever that is, is the key. Lower is better. The plus of the large viewing area in playback, becomes a pain when taking photos or videos, as it is ridiculously  easy to inadvertently take pictures or stop. But it's no problem deleting them, and having bought the largest (16GB, the camera won't take a 32GB ) memory card, I have never come close to filling it up. I have 1100+ pictures, and about twenty or thirty minutes of video stored on the card so far, and it tells me I still have room for 1000+ more. When I choose to upload to a computer, it's no problem.  I have taken pictures that are sharp, bright and clear, filling up the entire computer screen with stunning clarity. So I know it can do that. There are a couple of reviews on here by professional photographers that use this as kind of a 'Polaroid' to demo angles, lighting and such. They gave five stars. Both commented on the ISO setting. Keep that in mind. As of today, a brand new red one of these is being sold for $120. Get it!

Reviews.Title: Don't waste your money!
Reviews.Author: Elizabeth Brentwood "Litmom"
Reviews.Content: My father bought this camera for me as an "upgrade" to my Nikon Coolpix S220, which I had dropped, breaking the lens.  My father is an "early adopter" type and was interested in all of the advertised features.  In short, the camera has been a total nightmare. When you try to take a photo, whether you are using the touch screen or the more traditional button at the top of the camera, there is a 3-4 second delay between the moment you "click" and the moment when the actual photo is taken.  Consequently, subjects move, your hand jiggles, etc.  About 3 out of 4 of my photos are blurry and have to be discarded.  My entire family curses this camera, because it has engendered so many "retakes."  While this is the main problem with the camera, there are other annoying features, such as the fact that a simple process like turning off the flash is non-intuitive.I have been taking photos for years, with digital and film cameras, and have taken some great amateur shots.  In the one year I have owned this camera, I can honestly say that I have not taken one good shot (out of hundreds of attempts!).If you are deciding between this camera and another Nikon, I would strongly advise you to spend less money and get one of the Nikon Coolpix with the traditional lens and button mechanism.  My only caveat would be "don't drop it!"  The lens proved very fragile on my s220, but boy, do I miss those sharp photos!

Reviews.Title: Great little camera
Reviews.Author: John S. Bourman "cameramantwo"
Reviews.Content: Seems some love it and some loath it.  What are the problems and the "fix".Takes sharp, right on color, and easy to use operationProblem: fuzzy pix.  This is caused by two problems.1.  Shooting from the screen.  This is a questionable practice as the pressure to take the photo will cause movement that even the best vibration technique cannot over come.  Instant solution.  Use the "button" on top.2.  Failing to allow camera to focus - wait for the green brackets, then continue to press the shutter button down.  I have found from empirical evidence that many will press part way, the camera focuses, then they instantly release the button and press it again - many times totally unaware they are doing that.  Solution - press part way, allow the camera to focus then continue to press to release the shutter.  Your care in this process will result in excellent photographs.3.  Picture quality.  Unless you need a high ISO, use ISO under 200.  Anything above that will result in excessive noise.  Note, there is software available that can remove much of the camera noise which appears as black and gray specs in the image.4.  Remember, this is NOT a DSLR.  It, like all the other cameras of it's size has a little sensor.  I mean really little, and to jam 12.1 million pixels on such a tiny chip is a great accomplishment.  Do not expect results like a DSLR, or high end APC sensor size.  Ain't gonna happen.  However, for a small pocket and/or purse size this camera will not disappoint regardless of what other's may be experiencing.  Follow the notes above and you will have a great little camera with a wonderful view screen.

Reviews.Title: A camera is only as good as the photographer behind it
Reviews.Author: mabelle
Reviews.Content: I have a large Nikon and really wanted a small point and shoot for more every day use.  I knew I wanted a large LCD screen, which the S70 has. I really like the sleek compact design. I am a disappointed with the zoom quality since it is an internal zoom, but for serious pictures I have my large Nikon.  At first I was a bit disappointed by the picture quality but as I played with the settings I learned how to manipulate the camera in different lighting, setting , and subject.  A lot of reviews blasted the picture quality, but a camera is as good as the photographer behind it. The camera won't turn out amazing pictures just because it is a nice camera.  It is not that easy to use and it takes time to set up a picture.  I was really happy with the camera until my internal zoom malfunctioned and caused everything to be blurry. I sent it to Nikon to get repaired and they are working on it now. I bought the camera when it came out, about full price and I am ashamed to see the price drop so much.  When I questioned Nikon about it they said they were not allowed to divulge that information.  It seems that this camera has a defect and a lot of reviews I found have the touch screen stop working.  I still love the camera since it does what I wanted it to do.. take quick pictures and is compact.  I am just disappoined in Nikon for not working out the issues before they put it on the market.  I expected much better of Nikon.

The on-screen display was intuitive and easy to use.  Pictures can be taken using a button on top of the camera or by tapping the touch-screen. The quality of the still pictures HD videos is very good. The battery life is surprising long for a camera that has no optical view-finder (the screen has to be turned on to take pictures).To sum things up - this camera is small, well built and captures high quality images.I'm very pleased with every aspect of this camera, and highly recommend it.

Reviews.Title: Nice try for first-gen OLED
Reviews.Author: P. Sevcik
Reviews.Content: * It has OLED, so that conserves battery.  Nice.  * When it came out, it was at $400.  Now you can get it for $265..and it's about 3 months later. Ouch.Bottom Line:  I am going to sell the S70 I have (black/black) because it's really not what I wanted and with how quickly the price dropped, it's costing me dearly to be an early adopter. Reviews.Title: Make sure to cap the Auto ISO setting to 80-200
Reviews.Author: M. Lopez "California Groovin"
Reviews.Content: I have not tried the S70 yet (so disregard star rating) but I have noticed several reviews with the other color models noting frustrations about poor image quality. I also saw in the CNET Editor's review that they suggested that the user sets the Auto ISO limit to 80-200 for best results in most conditions and 80-400 max under difficult lighting conditions. So anyone who is experiencing photo quality issues might want to try that to see if it has a dramatic improvement. CNET said the pictures were "very good for a snapshot camera" once those settings have been changed. My guess is for some reason the camera is trying to take a ridiculously high ISO (1200-6400) and producing grainier photos as a result. As Wikipedia explains regarding ISO speeds, "In both digital and film photography, the reduction of exposure corresponding to use of higher sensitivities generally leads to reduced image quality (via coarser film grain or higher image noise of other types)." If that is in fact the problem it would still be a design flaw but one with perhaps a simple and tolerable workaround.From the CNET S70 review:"The photo quality from the S70 is very good for a snapshot camera...The camera lets you limit the auto ISO range to either 80-200 or 80-400. If you're in daylight or bright conditions, I recommend locking it down to 80-200. Again, it did perform well through ISO 400, but it's at its best below ISO 200."[...]Good luck with that workaround.I still like the specs of this camera so plan to check it out at the local Best Buy with my own SD card and I will be playing with these settings and I will update my review once I have.

Reviews.Title: Stay away!
Reviews.Author: Robert Swanson
Reviews.Content: Well, reading the reviews should be enough to confuse anyone about the camera. Many people share the same story, that it has been difficult or impossible to get good pictures from this camera. Others declare that they are well pleased with the quality of the photos. One thing for sure, the experiences with the camera are not universal. It's important to note that none of these are professional cameras. They are meant to be a simple to use camera, that produces a good picture. If I hired a professional photograher and he showed up with a compact, I'd fire him on the spot. That said, this is my second CoolPix. The first one, an S60, was purchased in July 09, and works like a champ. It was replacing an ancient Sony Cybershot 3.2 MP that has always worked well. The S60 produces very clear pictures that you can zoom in on or enlarge and still looks clear. It has a variety of easy to use advanced options that allow a more knowledgeable photographer flexibility and creativity. In November I purchased the S70 for use at work. The S70 shares these features, but not the picture quality. Originally, when we discovered how poor the pictures looked, we thought there must have been some setting that needed changed. I guessed that perhaps it was in a minimal dpi setting for email sized photos. Not so. No amount of experimenting could improve it. On the highest resolution setting, photos come out grainy and blurry. No amount of Photoshopping makes the pictures good. I have joked that they put the decimal in the wrong place, that it should be 1.2 Megapixel. Honestly, the 3.2 MP camera on my phone takes much better pictures.It's hard to say why there is such disparity in the reviews. Some certainly is user opinion or experience level. I think it is likely that the cameras are inconsistent from the factory. Perhaps some are manufactured at different facilities or different product runs had different internal components. Bottom line, if you see a good deal on one, be prepared to test it out personally and potentially need to return it.

Reviews.Title: Impossible to take a decent picture
Reviews.Author: missylf
Reviews.Content: When the camera first came out I was excited and impressed with the appearance and the touch screen. Even the pictures that weren't blurry were not crisp and clear.  Coming from using cheap disposables for a few years, I figured surely I would be impressed with a $400 camera.  Unfortunately, I am back to using disposables!  I just recently had a new baby, and I took several disposables to the hospital with me because I knew I couldn't depend on the coolpix s70 to produce any quality pictures.  I read the manuel and readjusted settings, researched the internet for advice on improving the picture taking quality, and called the manufacturer for advice...nothing worked!  I even asked a very techy camera guru friend of mine to please play with the camera for me to see if it was just me.  We came to the conclusion that "it is impossible to take a good picture with this camera"!  My friends and family who have tried to use the camera at gatherings have also commented to me how poor the picture quality is and several have complained the camera is hard to use.  I am extremely disappointed.  Also, I could never ask anybody else to take a picture because the screen would always get touched.  The camera also has a significant delay while shooting and in between pictures.  The only good thing I can say about the camera is the screen is impressive, but if it can't take pictures then the camera is worthless to me.

Reviews.Title: DEPENDS ON YOUR OWN EXPECTATIONS
Reviews.Author: Donna
Reviews.Content: Mainly, hate the floating image in the monitor.  It is hard to focus precisely if you do not have a perfectly steady hand.  In order to take a well-focused, clear photo indoors or outdoors, you need a tripod.  Even with Handshake feature on, still takes blurred picture if hand is not perfectly steady. On tripod, still time-consuming just to get your subject well focused.  Outside as hard to see in bright light as cell phone monitor.  Hard to manipulate camera without getting finger in way of lens or accidentally pressing shutter-release button while focusing.  Also needs frequent cleaning, since monitor gets smeared with fingerprints from handling camera. The "big" monitor might sound good, but big does not necessarily mean better.  I prefer the traditional viewfinder.Furthermore, my Coolpix is six months old, and the monitor developed a green tinge in upper left hand corner so when viewing images they are tinged green in that area.  This discoloration is not there in images uploaded to computer.  I found in the manual under Notes On the Monitor:  OLED monitors are susceptible to screen burn.  I don't know if that is what the green tinge is but may be.  The monitor is my main complaint.  Minor issues: cover over cable connector difficult & clumsy to open; as nice as Touch Panel is. . . easy to inadvertently trigger options you don't want or release shutter before you are ready. Overall, all features neat and quality okay for everyday snapshot-type picture taking.  I did get some good digital photos that printed out nicely on my Brother printer.  In fact, I printed a few on watercolor paper, matted & framed them & they look great.  I got the Coolpix as a gift from someone who thinks the name Nikon means God's Chosen One (I am an old Pentax fan) and am looking to replace it with a RAW file camera, Amazon has a good deal on a Panasonic.

Reviews.Title: Nikon Tried But Didn't Come Through
Reviews.Author: Dr. B. Gubar "Sports Car Enthusiast"
Reviews.Content: This camera isn't of the quality that Nikon is known for.There are some positives going for it:1. Size: it's small enough to put into either a shirt pocket or pants pocket.  Great to carry around for those occasions when you want to have a camera handy.2. Lens Cover:  Unlike some of the other CoolPix cameras, this one has a cover for the lens.  That might not seem like a big deal, but after having a scratched lens from other things in your pocket, it's helpful.3. Rapid On and Off:  Sometimes you just don't have the time to wait for the camera to slowly turn on or off, or have an available flash.  This camera has a rapid on/off cycle.Cons:1. Picture Quality:  Probably the most important thing that should be considered when buying any camera is picture quality.  The pictures produced by the S70 seems to be grainy whether day or night, using either the telephoto or wide angle functions. Changing the resolution didn't help with the grainy photographs.2. Touch Screen:  While a nice touch (no pun intended), it can be difficult to use. In colder weather, the touch screen isn't as responsive as necessary (Touch the screen to activate the shutter). There can be quite a lag in the time between touching the screen and the shutter going off. Don't expect to get a quick response in winter.3. Slow Speed: Great for posed photos, but for any sort of faster action, most of the pictures are blurry. Again, the speed of the shutter on the CoolPix S70 is great for candid party shots or snaps of buildings or other landmarks while on vacation, but not for sporting events.Bottom Line:While the CoolPix S70 is compact and handy, the quality of the pictures produced are not very good.  To be perfectly candid (again, no pun intended), other than the Nikon name, there really isn't anything here that deserves the moniker.  Smartphone cameras (I have an iPhone 3GS), have the same quality. If you're looking for a cheap camera with the Nikon name, this is it.  Unfortunately, the CoolPix S70, was a good concept that just didn't work.  There are lots of bells and whistles, but the bottom line is the resulting photograph. If you'd like a small camera to take mediocre photos, stick to the cellphone camera.  If you are looking for a better quality, either invest more in a better camera, or look to another brand.

Reviews.Title: I wanted to like this, but it's so flawed
Reviews.Author: xjohnnyrocketx
Reviews.Content: When I saw the camera in action, I really wanted to like it.  I liked all the features it had to offer, but every feature did not work properly.  This camera is inherently flawed.  For every pro there is a con.  I did not want to believe the negative reviews on amazon, but I wish I had.  I ultimately had to return it because it just simply does not work as advertised.Pro (with it's con)- big OLED touchscreen.  ( that's awesome, but the resolution is so poor, it really is an eyesore to look at.  Colors look nice, but they do not truly represent the photo when transferred to a computer)- touch controls, virtually no buttons except the shutter. Controls include iPhone like pinch to zoom and swiping through picture functionality. (this feature would be nice had they either put better hardware in the camera or made the firmware more efficient.  The controls are so slow and unresponsive, it will make you downright mad.  Touch focus is horrific and never works as it is supposed to.  Also, no dedicated power button means you must open the lens up to turn it on, even to review pictures.  Come on, that's ridiculous.)-high resolution sensor capable of taking HD 720p video. (I should live with the afformemtioned flaws above, but it must do it's primary function well, taking a nice clear picture.  This camera does not.  The pictures look simply bad.  My 5 year old Sanyo Xacti digicam takes superior pictures to this camera.  This is not an exaggeration.  Pictures are not properly set up by the camera, and are often taken incorrectly.  Previewing the pictures on the camera show rich vibrant color, but transferring them to a computer show them to be dull, with improper color representation.  Video is no better.  It looks to be captured via motion jpeg format.  Framerates are bad, colors look as dull and misrepresented as in stills.  Also, no optical zoom while shooting video.  Just everything wrong going on here.)A few nice things that I really can't complain about is the build quality is superb.  Also, the all interenal optics is great so if you are storing it in a purse or pocket, the lens will not protrude accidentally causing harm to the camera. This cannot make up for the fact that a) it's primary function, taking pictures is severly flawed, and b) Its main selling point, the huge multitouch OLED display looks horrific and does not Function properly.I honestly cannot recommend this item, and would recommend a comparable camera from another manufacturer.

Reviews.Title: Make sure to cap the Auto ISO setting to 80-200
Reviews.Author: M. Lopez "California Groovin"
Reviews.Content: I have not tried the S70 yet (so disregard star rating) but I have noticed several reviews with frustrations about poor image quality. I also saw in the CNET Editor's review that they suggested that the user sets the Auto ISO limit to 80-200 for best results in most conditions and 80-400 max under difficult lighting conditions. So anyone who is experiencing photo quality issues might want to try that to see if it has a dramatic improvement. CNET said the pictures were "very good for a snapshot camera" once those settings have been changed. My guess is for some reason the camera is trying to take a ridiculously high ISO (1200-6400) and producing grainier photos as a result. As Wikipedia explains regarding ISO speeds, "In both digital and film photography, the reduction of exposure corresponding to use of higher sensitivities generally leads to reduced image quality (via coarser film grain or higher image noise of other types)." If that is in fact the problem it would still be a design flaw but one with perhaps a simple and tolerable workaround.[...]"The photo quality from the S70 is very good for a snapshot camera...The camera lets you limit the auto ISO range to either 80-200 or 80-400. If you're in daylight or bright conditions, I recommend locking it down to 80-200. Again, it did perform well through ISO 400, but it's at its best below ISO 200."[...]Good luck with that workaround.I still like the specs of this camera so plan to check it out at the local Best Buy with my own SD card and I will be playing with these settings and I will update my review once I have.

What I got was extremely poor quality pictures only bigger.Reviews had mentioned this but the professional reviews rated the camera fairly favorably. I assume that the professionals only tested the camera in the lab. Picture quality at best is pretty bad. At worst, the picture is so blurry as to be impossible to tell what the subject was. A courtroom sketch would have come out better. I realize that some of this had to do with the settings and the fact that it was difficult to remember to change the settings for each shot.Another problem had to do with the touch screen. It was almost impossible to take a picture without touching one of the icons on the screen. In some cases the picture taking process was reduced to listening to the camera constantly changing some button or other. Reviews had mentioned this but I just thought that people needed to be more careful. It's almost impossible to be careful with this camera. And you can just forget about asking someone to take a picture for you. Very bad design.I fell with the camera protected in a case and it still broke. It appears that the CCD is mounted on silicon to reduce vibration and that must have torn. Everything on the camera still works but the colors are misaligned yielding purpleish pictures with weird lines throughout. This after only about 300 pictures on the camera. The really sad part is that I wish it had broken earlier so I wouldn't have missed some many one-chance-in-a-lifetime pictures.Do yourself a favor and find another camera, even another Nikon.

Reviews.Title: If looking for quality photos and easy UI, get a digital SLR
Reviews.Author: B. Ramsey
Reviews.Content: Nikon has some of the best optics around and has for many years.  I also have a digital SLR that was actually less expensive than this S-70.I mainly bought the S-70 for my wife's convenience and lack of tech skills.  Simple aim and shoot with some cool features to review pics and videos.  I also liked the idea of a compact for family events instead of lugging around my SLR all of the time.Nothing could be further from the truth with this camera.  Out of the box, without very good documentation either in softcover or online, it's a bit daunting to figure out all of the symbols without a lot of trial and error on the users part.  You would think the UI would atleast be friendly, however after being lead continuously down the path of dead-end menu structures with no real way to go 'back' to the previous menu, you tend to take the short cut of closing the camera to reset the menu so you can start over.Sound fun?  Wait, there's more!I figured, oh well, atleast there's the super simple mode, tap the simpleton icon, aim and ... tap ... tap ... tap.  The response time of tapping the screen or even using the shutter release button to take a picture is so slow and sometimes unresponsive that your friends and family are already looking at you like, "Will you hurry the %$*! up so I can get back to what I was doing before." "You paid what?!? for that piece of ..."  You get the 'picture'.I don't remember quality being a significant point in the commercials and it's a good thing.  With all the anti-motion and such, I am amazed at how much you have to make absolutely sure you're not even breathing when you take a shot.  Close to 9 out of 10 pics come out blurred because your heart beat more than 10 times during the extruciatingly slow electronic shutter release.  And forget low light or even night shots.  Those not only are mostly blurred due to the even slower response to capture more light, but the color quality and flash deciding whether or not to make up it's mind and actually flash is so inconsistant and spotty you and your audience are just hoping this thing will take a decent photo over the last 10 tries so everyone can get on with their life as this camera sucks the fun out of the trying to capture a 'Kodak' moment.And UI to Nikon must stand for Unsightly Icons.  There are more icons on the screen than picture.  And one out of the 2 dozen or so blocking your view actually reduces them by half!  How convenient!  Good luck on finding the one that does that!Well, atleast it's built well, right?  I hope the cheap plastic lens cover that slides in an incovenient way as to make you fumble for a bit to get it open, lasts for a year.  All other Nikon products I've ever had were built superior to most other mfg's, but so is the price.  It's suprising they would even consider putting this product to market, except for  the fact they are trying to greedily capture the 'instamatic' audience they really have no business to be bothering.Next time I really want to shell out some money for a camera, I sure won't be buying sight unseen through the internet. (My bad)  I suggest you go to your local retail camera outlet, try a dozen or so with the helpful guy trying to sell you at MSRP, and choose the one that fits you and your perception of quality, and then buy it on the internet with someone who will take it back due to purely your dissatisfaction of the product.I doubt Ashton Kutcher really ever used it.  And have you noticed he's hawking their digital SLR lately?Save yourself from frustration and dissappointment and pass on this Nikon camera.
